thoughts: Spanish letter “a” is identical to the open, un-stressed vowel English speakers use in words like “father.” It appears in all syllable positions, so there’s nothing exotic about where it shows up—only that Spanish keeps it pure (never turns into the “æ” of ‘cat’ or the schwa of ‘sofa’). Most learners already have the mouth shape and sound in their inventory, so the main job is remembering to pronounce it consistently.
description: Open your mouth wide and low, tongue relaxed and resting low in the mouth, lips unrounded—exactly like the “ah” in English “father.” Hold it briefly and clearly; don’t let it slide toward an “uh” (schwa) or the tighter “æ” of “cat.”

thoughts: English already has a strong /b/ plosive, but Spanish uses both a plosive [b] and a softer buzzy approximant [β̞] depending on position. Learners usually default to the English plosive everywhere; that’s understood, but they should also notice the lighter version between vowels.
description: In Spanish, the letter “b” represents a single sound family. After a pause or after an "m" or "n" you say a full voiced plosive, just like the English “b” in “ball.” Between vowels or other voiced sounds, Spanish relaxes it into a soft, lips-almost-touching glide (an airy, buzzing sound) rather than a hard stop. Imagine starting to say a “b” but letting the air flow without fully closing your lips—almost like a gentle vibration.

thoughts: English already uses the letter C for both /k/ and /s/, so learners will recognize the two main Spanish values. The only new twist is that Spaniards pronounce ce/ci as /θ/, but Latin-American /s/ will feel completely familiar. Articulation is identical to English hard C and English S; no new mouth movement required.
description:
The Spanish letter “c” has two regular pronunciations:
1. Hard C (/k/): When followed by a, o, u, or a consonant (ca, co, cu, cl…), it is the same voiceless K sound you make in English “cat.” The back of the tongue taps the soft palate; vocal cords stay off.
2. Soft C (/s/ in Latin America, /θ/ in most of Spain): When followed by e or i (ce, ci), Latin-American Spanish uses the voiceless S sound of English “see.” In Spain it is a voiceless TH as in “thin.” Either way, the sound remains unvoiced and airy.
Important differences from English: the Spanish hard C is crisper—never the aspirated “kh” puff some English speakers add; and the soft C is never the buzzing /z/ you might hear in English words like “city.”

example_words.cultural_context: Global soft-drink brand; you see the Spanish spelling on menus everywhere

thoughts: Spanish “d” alternates between a crisp English-like [d] (after a pause, after “n” or “l”) and a softer, quick “th” sound [ð] (like the “th” in “this”) everywhere else. English speakers know both sounds separately but not the rule for switching, so the sound is familiar yet the distribution causes some challenge.
description:
In Spanish, the letter “d” is pronounced in two ways:
1) Hard [d]: Place the tip of your tongue on the ridge just behind your upper front teeth, release with a small burst of voice. This happens at the start of a phrase or after an “n” or “l” (e.g., “día,” “andar”). It feels almost identical to the English “d.”
2) Soft [ð]: Keep the tongue in the same spot but let the air glide out without fully stopping—like the voiced “th” in English “this.” This softer version appears between vowels and after most consonants (e.g., “cada,” “nada”).

Key tip: Your tongue always touches the teeth ridge; never pull it back like many English speakers do in words such as “dog.”

thoughts: Spanish “e” is one of the five simple, pure vowels. English speakers already know a very similar sound (the vowel in “bet”), though English tends to stretch it or slide into a slight ‘y’ sound at the end. The biggest reminder is to keep it short and crisp.
description: A single, clean vowel made with the tongue pushed slightly forward and mid-high in the mouth—very much like the English vowel in “bed,” but shorter and without any glide. Lips stay relaxed, jaw barely opens, and the sound remains steady from start to finish.

thoughts: The Spanish letter “f” is pronounced exactly the same way as the English “f,” so English speakers won’t face any surprises. It can occur at the start, in the middle, or at the end of words, but its articulation never changes.
description: Push air through a small gap between your lower lip and upper front teeth without using your vocal cords—just like the English “f” in “fish.” In Spanish it is always this pure, unvoiced sound; it never shifts to a “v” or a softer sound.

thoughts: English speakers already know the hard “g” sound (as in “go”), but the soft Spanish “g” before e/i, pronounced like a throaty English “h” or the Scottish “loch,” is new. Because the letter can switch between these two values, learners must watch the following vowel to pick the right sound.
description:
Spanish “g” has TWO common pronunciations.
1. Hard g [g]: Before a, o, u, or a consonant, and in the cluster “gu + e/i” (guitarra). It is the same as the English g in “go.”
2. Soft g [x]: Before e or i (ge, gi). This is a voiceless throaty sound made by narrowing the back of the tongue against the soft palate—similar to the English “h” in “ahead” but stronger, or the Scottish “loch.”
Tip: Look at the next vowel—e/i = soft; anything else = hard.

thoughts: Spanish “h” is actually the absence of a sound, which surprises many learners. English speakers already know silent-letters (hour, honest), so the idea exists, but they must remember to keep Spanish completely un-aspirated every single time.
description: In modern standard Spanish the letter “h” is silent. You do not exhale or add any English-style /h/ before the following vowel or consonant; simply begin the word (or continue the syllable) as if the “h” were not written at all. Example: “hotel” is pronounced roughly “oh-TEL.” The only exception is when it combines as the separate digraph “ch,” which has its own /ch/ sound.

thoughts: Spanish “i” is practically the same pure high-front vowel found in many English words such as the first syllable of “machine.”  English speakers already make this sound, but they sometimes lengthen it into a glide (“ee-uh”) or relax it toward the lax “ih” in “sit.”  The key coaching point is to keep it short and tense.
description: A short, tense “ee” sound.  Lips are slightly spread, jaw nearly closed, and the front of the tongue is raised close to the roof of the mouth without touching it.  It should stay pure—no glide or change in quality from start to finish.

thoughts: The Spanish letter “j” represents a harsh, breathy sound that does not exist as a separate phoneme in English, though English speakers have heard it in common Mexican food names and place names. They usually think it is just an “h,” but the tongue and throat position make it stronger and raspier. The sound can appear anywhere in a word.
description: Spanish “j” is a voiceless velar—or slightly uvular—fricative. Start as if you were going to say the English “k,” but instead of stopping the air, keep the back of the tongue close to the soft palate and let air pass through, creating a raspy, throaty friction. It is much stronger than the English “h” in “hat,” almost like clearing your throat gently.

example_words.cultural_context: Common spicy pepper listed on menus and in grocery stores

thoughts: The Spanish /k/ is produced the same way as the English hard “k,” but it is never followed by the strong puff of air (aspiration) that English speakers unconsciously add at the start of stressed syllables. Because English already has this consonant, learners mainly need to remember to keep it crisp and unaspirated. The sound is spelled several ways in Spanish (c, qu, k), so the bigger challenge is recognizing the different spellings rather than making the sound.
description: Touch the back of your tongue to the soft palate, stop the airflow, then release it quickly—like the English “k” in the word “ski.” Do NOT add the extra burst of air you hear in English words like “kay.”

thoughts: Spanish uses the same “clear-L” that English speakers already pronounce at the start of words like “light.” There is no “dark-L” as in English word-final position, but that doesn’t create major problems for learners.
description: Place the tip of your tongue lightly against the ridge just behind your upper front teeth and let the air flow around the sides of the tongue. Keep the sound short and light—do not add the velar, ‘dark’ quality many English speakers produce at the end of words like “ball.”

example_words.cultural_context: Common term in English-language media for people of Latin American heritage

thoughts: Spanish “m” is the same bilabial nasal found in English, so learners already know the mouth position and voicing. The only thing to remember is that Spanish keeps it crisp, without the vowel-lengthening that sometimes happens in English.
description: Close both lips, let the vocal cords vibrate, and allow air to resonate through the nose while keeping the mouth closed. It’s the same sound as the English “m” in “moon” or “summer,” produced quickly and clearly in Spanish.

thoughts: Spanish “n” is exactly the same sound as the English “n” in words like “no” or “ten.” English speakers have no new articulation to learn; they only have to remember that it can show up anywhere in a Spanish word.
description: It is the voiced alveolar nasal. Place the tongue tip against the ridge just behind your upper front teeth (the alveolar ridge) and let the air resonate through your nasal cavity while voicing. It is identical to the English “n.”

thoughts: English speakers have already run into “ñ” in food names and weather reports. The sound itself exists in English (the “ny” in “canyon”), so recognition is high, but matching it consistently in Spanish words and remembering the tilde can still be tricky.
description: Pronounce it like the “ny” in the English word “canyon.” Start with an “n” but let the middle of your tongue rise to touch the roof of the mouth just behind the teeth, creating a quick ‘y’ glide right after the ‘n’—one blended sound: /ny/.

thoughts: Spanish “o” is essentially the same pure mid-back rounded vowel many English speakers already use in words like “go,” but without the final glide toward a “w” sound. Because the sound exists in English, learners usually recognize and reproduce it quickly; the main adjustment is to keep it short and steady.
description: Pronounce it as a single, short, pure “oh” sound. Keep your lips rounded but relaxed, tongue in the mid-back position, and do NOT let the vowel slide toward a ‘w’ or ‘oo.’ It should be one clean, steady vowel lasting about the length of a single beat.

example_words.cultural_context: Common Spanish greeting frequently heard in beginner courses, travel apps, and pop culture

thoughts: Spanish /p/ is almost the same sound English speakers already use; the only trick is remembering that Spanish does not add the strong puff of air (aspiration) that English has at the start of stressed syllables.
description: It is a voiceless bilabial stop: close both lips, build a little pressure, then release quickly. In Spanish the release is soft—keep your vocal cords off and avoid the noticeable burst of air you usually make in English at the beginning of a word like “pie.” Hold a hand in front of your mouth: you should feel almost no air when saying the Spanish /p/. Between vowels it sounds the same but even shorter.

example_words.cultural_context: Tropical fruit found in smoothies and grocery stores everywhere

thoughts: English speakers already know the /k/ sound. In Spanish the letter “q” is simply another way to spell that sound when it comes before e or i, with a silent u. Biggest surprise is that the written u is not heard.
description: In Spanish the letter “q” (always written as “qu” before the vowels e or i) is pronounced exactly like the hard “k” sound in English words such as “kite” or “skate.” The back of your tongue briefly touches the soft palate and releases a small burst of air. The written “u” is completely silent—your lips do not round and you do not create a /w/ sound.

example_words.cultural_context: Popular Mexican stuffed tortilla available at many fast-food chains and restaurants

thoughts: Spanish “r” actually covers two related sounds: a quick single-tap (flap) that occurs between vowels, and a stronger multi-vibration trill that appears at the beginning of a word or when written “rr.” English already has a hidden flap in words like “butter,” but has no trill, so learners will partly recognize the feel but still face something new.
description:
Tap version: Touch the tip of your tongue quickly to the ridge just behind your upper front teeth—so fast it feels like a soft, single click of the tongue (similar to the very quick sound Americans make in the middle of “butter”).
Trill version: Use the same tongue placement but force more air, letting the tongue vibrate two or more times—like a tiny motor. Keep airflow steady and relaxed; the vibration happens passively when the tongue is in the right spot.

thoughts: The Spanish “s” is essentially the same voiceless ‘s’ sound English speakers use in words like “sun” or “bus.” It does not change before vowels and never becomes the /z/ sound, so it is very familiar and easy for English learners.
description: A hissing, voiceless sound made by letting air pass between the tongue and the ridge behind the upper teeth (the same as the English “s” in “snake”). In Spanish it always stays an unvoiced /s/; it never turns into a /z/.

thoughts: English speakers already know the basic /t/ sound, but the Spanish version is slightly different: it is dental (tongue against upper teeth) and unaspirated (no strong puff of air). Since the articulatory change is small and the sound is common, it should be easy for most learners once they become aware of the lack of aspiration.
description: In Spanish, /t/ is a voiceless dental stop. Place the tip of your tongue lightly against the back of your upper front teeth (not on the ridge just behind them as in English). Release the tongue without a strong burst of air—think of it as a softer, crisper ‘t’ than in English words like “top.”

thoughts: Spanish “u” is almost identical to the English vowel in “food.” English speakers already make this sound, but they need to keep it short and pure, without turning it into a diphthong (no glide toward a w-sound).
description: A single, pure vowel made with the tongue high and toward the back of the mouth, lips rounded – like the “oo” in English “food.” Hold it briefly and evenly; do not let it slide or change quality.

thoughts: English speakers already know the written letter “v,” but in Spanish it’s not the English /v/. Spanish “v” sounds almost identical to Spanish “b,” produced with the lips (bilabial), not the teeth. The main hurdle is breaking the English habit of touching the top teeth to the bottom lip. Because the mouth movement is similar to the English “b,” the concept is familiar, but the habit change takes some practice.
description:
In Spanish, the letter “v” is pronounced the same as the Spanish “b.”
• At the start of a breath-group or after a pause/nasal (m, n), it is a hard bilabial plosive [b]—lips close firmly, short pop of air, vocal cords vibrate.
• Between vowels or most other consonants, it relaxes into a soft bilabial approximant [β̞]—lips come close without fully closing; it sounds like a very soft, buzzing-less “b.”
Key point: Your lips—not your teeth—do the work. Do NOT touch the top teeth to the bottom lip as in the English /v/.

thoughts: The Spanish letter “w” is almost always found in loan-words or proper names taken from other languages. Spaniards therefore pronounce it the way they hear it in those foreign words, which for modern Spanish generally matches the English sound /w/ (as in “water”). Because the articulation and lip rounding are identical to English, native English speakers should find it instantly familiar and easy to reproduce.
description: Make a small, tight circle with your lips (as if beginning to whistle) and voice a quick glide while letting air flow: /w/. It is the same sound you make at the start of English words like “we” or “wine.” In Spanish it never represents any other sound; if you can say English “w,” you already have it.

thoughts: Spanish “x” usually sounds like the English “x” in eXit (/ks/), so that part feels familiar, but some very common words (México, Texas) use an /h/-like sound instead. English speakers know the words, yet don’t expect the second pronunciation, which raises the challenge slightly.
description: Most of the time, Spanish “x” is pronounced like the English consonant cluster /ks/—one quick burst, no extra vowel (ta-ksi for “taxi”).  However, in a handful of historic or place names (México, Texas, Oaxaca, Xochimilco) it is pronounced like a soft English “h.”  The mouth is open, airflow continuous, and the back of the tongue approaches (but doesn’t touch) the roof of the mouth—similar to exhaling fog on glass.  Context or memorization tells you which value to use.

thoughts: Most English speakers already know the consonant sound of Spanish “y” because it is almost identical to the English “y” in “yes.” In some regions Spanish speakers make it a bit more “soft-j/zh” sounding, but using an English y is acceptable for beginners. The only surprise is that when the letter stands alone (the word "y" meaning “and”) it is pronounced like the vowel “ee.”
description: As a consonant, pronounce it like the y in English “yes”: tongue high and close to the hard palate, air flowing smoothly without friction. Avoid turning it into a harsh English “j.” When the letter y stands alone as the word for “and,” pronounce it like the long e sound “ee.”

thoughts: English speakers already know both sounds that Spanish “z” can make: either the un-voiced “th” of “thin” (common in Spain) or the un-voiced “s” of “see” (common across Latin America). The new idea is that Spanish never uses the buzzing “z” of “zebra.” So the challenge is not making a new sound, but remembering which one to use.
description: In most of Spain, the letter “z” is pronounced like the voiceless “th” in English “thin”—tongue lightly between the teeth, air passes out without vibration. In nearly all of Latin America, the same letter is pronounced like a clear, hissy English “s.” It is always voiceless and never the buzzy “z” of English “zoo.”

thoughts: English already has the same open “ah” vowel as in “father,” so the actual mouth position is familiar; what’s new is noticing the written accent, which simply marks the stressed syllable.
description: á is the same open-back ‘ah’ vowel you hear in the English word “father.”  Your jaw drops, lips are relaxed (not rounded), and the tongue is low and slightly forward.  The written accent does NOT change the sound itself; it just shows where the word’s main stress falls.

thoughts: Spanish “é” is simply the regular vowel “e” with an accent mark that tells you it gets the main stress. The actual mouth position is the same every time: a pure, short, mid-front vowel. It sits between the English vowels in “bet” and the first part of “bay,” but it never glides to a “y” sound. English speakers have heard it in many borrowed words, so the sound is familiar; the main challenge is keeping it short and pure.
description: Open your mouth slightly, lips relaxed and unrounded. Place your tongue mid-high and toward the front, as for the first half of the English diphthong in “day,” but stop there—do NOT let it slide into a “y” sound. Keep it short and clear. The written accent just tells you this syllable is stressed; it does not change the vowel quality.

thoughts: The accented í is simply the regular Spanish “i” (/i/) with a written accent to show that the syllable carries the stress. English already has an identical vowel in words like “machine” or “see,” so the only real new idea is noticing the written accent and stressing that syllable.
description: It is the same pure “ee” sound you hear in English words like “machine,” but in Spanish it is always short and crisp—never glides into a “y.” The written accent (´) only tells you that this syllable gets the stress.

thoughts: Spanish ó is not a new vowel for English speakers—the acute accent only tells you that the syllable is stressed. The actual sound is a pure, single “o” (close-mid, back, rounded). The only challenge is avoiding the English glide that turns “o” into “oh-oo.”
description: Pronounce it like the first part of English “go,” but stop before your lips move into the little "w" glide. Keep your lips rounded, keep the vowel short and steady, and put extra stress on the syllable because of the accent mark.

thoughts: The accented "ú" is simply the regular Spanish vowel /u/ (like the “oo” in English “food”) but marked to receive the main stress of the word. So the sound itself is familiar; the main new point is remembering that the written accent tells you where to put the stress.
description: Pronounce it like the long “oo” in English “food,” keeping the lips rounded and the tongue high and toward the back of the mouth. The written accent mark (´) just means this syllable is stressed; it does not change the vowel quality.

thoughts: The Spanish ü simply forces the letter “u” to be heard after g and before e/i, producing the same glide as the English “w.” English speakers already use this sound every day; the only new part is seeing it written with two dots.
description: Ü is pronounced like the English w-sound. In Spanish it normally appears in the groups güe and güi. Say a quick w and immediately move into the following vowel: güe = “gweh,” güi = “gwee.” Nothing in the lips, tongue, or throat is new—just remember to pronounce the u instead of leaving it silent.

thoughts: English already has the same "ch" sound (as in “chocolate”), so learners possess a ready-made reference. In Spanish the spelling–sound match is very consistent, which lowers difficulty.
description: Pronounce it exactly like the English "ch" in “chocolate” or “chair”: start with the tip of the tongue touching the ridge just behind the upper teeth (like a quick ‘t’) and immediately release into a strong ‘sh’ sound, producing one crisp affricate [tʃ]. Spanish keeps this sound short and clear—never turn it into a soft ‘sh’ or a hard ‘k’.

thoughts: English speakers have already seen the double-l in food words like “tortilla.” In most Spanish today it’s pronounced like the English consonant Y in “yes,” so it doesn’t add a brand-new mouth movement, but learners must remember not to read it as the English L or as two separate letters. Regional variants (zh/sh sounds) exist, but the Y-sound is the safest neutral choice.
description: In modern standard Spanish, the letter pair “ll” is pronounced as a single consonant that sounds like the English y in “yes.” Place the middle of your tongue close to (but not touching) the hard palate and let the air flow smoothly while voicing. Do NOT touch the tongue to the teeth or alveolar ridge as you would for an English L. In many Latin-American regions this “ll” is identical to the Spanish letter “y.” (Some areas pronounce it more like the “zh” in “measure,” but the y-sound will be understood everywhere.)

thoughts: English has no rolled-R, so learners have likely heard it in words like “burrito” but seldom produce it. They must learn the tongue-tip trill.
description: Spanish “rr” is an alveolar trill (a rolled R). Place the tip of your tongue lightly against the small ridge just behind your upper front teeth (the alveolar ridge). Let a steady airstream pass so the tongue tip vibrates rapidly—at least two quick taps—in a series of very short flaps. Do NOT use the back of the throat; the sound is made with the tongue tip and airflow, similar to a rapid motorboat sound.

thoughts: English speakers already know the /k/ sound, but they may try to pronounce the written “u.” Main tip: treat “qu” before e or i exactly like the hard “k” in “kite,” with no following “w.”
description: In Spanish, the letter pair “qu” is pronounced as a single hard K sound /k/. The written “u” is completely silent and there is no “w” glide afterward. It only appears before the vowels e or i (que, qui). Make the same back-of-the-tongue contact you use for an English K in “sky,” release cleanly, and go straight into the next vowel.
